utterances: The whole night?
When the time came to come home, the Cuban government would let her.
So, my dad was here in Miami working and desperate, because his family - they would let my sister come because she was a U.S.
citizen, but they wouldn't let my brother and my mom come.
And they would go to the airport every day for nine months waiting to be let go, and then finally were able to come.
So, it was very frightening.
And I think that's what they do for sure that that's not the place they wanted to be.
Rubio's spokesman Alex Conant and writes in an email that the senator's mother was indeed told she could not leave Cuba and that only her infant daughter born in the U.S.
could return to the U.S.
Eventually, Conant says, they were all allowed to leave together.

But rather than the nine months forced wait that Rubio described two years ago to NPR, Rubio - in the latest version of his family story - says they arrived in Cuba in February of 1961 and left the following month.
Still, he writes: I am the son of exiles, a cherished status for many in Florida.
David Welna, NPR News, the Capital.
And ALL THINGS CONSIDERED continues in a moment.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
We still have a window on Iran's political turmoil despite the government's best efforts to close it.
Iran has blocked or slowed down many Web sites, yet some messages are still getting through.
And in a moment we'll find out how a man in Oklahoma is helping that to happen.
Iran's government has also sent home many Western journalists following a disputed election.
But some reporters have the right to stay, because they're Iranian nationals.
One is Borzou Daragahi of the Los Angeles Times.
We asked him about the protests and about the government's response.
It hasn't been really mass arrests.
People have been arrested - generally a lot of the people who are arrested are held overnight, you know, roughed up a bit, and let go with a warning in an attempt to quiet them and intimidate them.
At this point, it seems like both sides are kind of gauging each other's limitations and capabilities.
Neither side is quite sure how far the other side is willing to go in terms of pressing its demands.
So what have the demonstrations been like as they've moved from day to day?
Well, these are very, very large gatherings of people.

And it is interesting from what we understand that, you know, as the days have gone on these demonstrators have been gathering with increasing confidence and motivation, and less and less worry about the consequences of being at these events.
Generally, people are quiet.
They don't want to chant slogans, because they're afraid that it will provoke the authorities.

And they hold up signs that say where is my vote and many of them wrap green bandanas or fabric around their faces, around their mouths to shield their identities from the ubiquitous security officials that are watching from the sidelines or perhaps from adjacent buildings.
There's a worry among some people that the government will wait for these things to die down and then one by one go after some of the people at these demonstrations.
There seem to be some - I wouldn't call them ring leaders, but people who are experienced at organizing this kind of stuff.
And they kind of do a little bit of crowd management, move the people over so that the cars can pass, tell people to stop and let the people catch up.
And those folks, from what we understand, many are former or long time student activists, university activists, women's rights activists - and those folks are the ones who mostly shield their faces.
Might some of these be activists who remember being activists in 1979, when Iran had a revolution?

You know, this whole thing - although there's all sorts of people who are involved in this from all walks of life, especially the march on Monday and the one Wednesday, yesterday - this is a movement that is being driven by the young people who don't remember - they weren't even born anywhere near the revolution.
Many of them were born nine, ten, you know, eleven, twelve years after the revolution, you know - so they don't remember.
They've only heard about this from history books and classes.
So they don't have that kind of background.

But there is a very strong possibility, because of the unique nature of the coalition that's formed that there are people behind the scenes who are even pillars of the establishment who are providing logistical and other types of support.
I'm thinking, mainly the kind of so-called pragmatic, conservative old guard, such as Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who is explicitly against Ahmadinejad.
One other thing.
We know what the protestors don't like.
They feel that the election was stolen from them.
But do they know exactly what they want?
Do they know exactly what they want the government to do that the government might agree to do?
Well, look, let me just be kind of carefully clear about what this is kind of about, in our assessment.
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad represents a certain segment of the Iranian population - and perhaps maybe even a majority -of pious, lower middle class, - a very distinct segment of the Iranians.
But there are other types of Iranians.
There's ethnic minorities, religious minorities.
There's secular liberals.
There's pious Iranians, who nonetheless, are much more tolerant than that particular segment.
And the problem the people have with Ahmadinejad is that he rules and he governs in a style as if none of those others matter or exist and that only his segment counts.
And that's the root of the problem at this point, because it's not really about his election.
It's about Ahmadinejad.
That's Borzou Deragahi, reporter for the Los Angeles Times in Tehran.
In Ivory Coast, the outcome of last November's presidential election remains in dispute.
Two men continue to claim victory, and it's now fueling a propaganda battle.
NPR's Ofeibea Quist-Arcton reports that the incumbent president, Laurent Gbagbo, maintains control of the powerful national television station.
His challenger, Alassane Ouattara, is working out of a hotel.
He's protected by U.N.
peacekeepers, but he has little access to the world outside the hotel gates.
(Soundbite of television program)
Unidentified Man #1: (Foreign language spoken)
The dominant media voice here in Ivory Coast is state-run television, RTI, which is a vital weapon in the arsenal of Laurent Gbagbo.
After a decade in office, his critics say Gbagbo is clinging to power despite losing November's presidential vote.
Political analyst Gilles Yabi heads the International Crisis Group in West Africa.
Yabi says Gbagbo's camp uses primetime television to demonize all who question his leadership, including presidential challenger Alassane Ouattara, the U.N.
and President Obama.
The role of the media is very important.
The strategy of Laurent Gbagbo is the control.
There is no debate, there is no dissenting voices.
(Soundbite of television program)
Unidentified Man #2: (Foreign language spoken)
An endless stream of pro-Gbagbo supporters parades in front of the TV cameras.
They criticize international pressure and portray West Africa's threat to use force to remove Gbagbo as a plot to impose war on Ivory Coast.
Analyst Yabi says it's all meant to support Gbagbo's claim that he won the vote.
And then when you control the national television, you can give a sense that you enjoy massive support in the country by bringing experts who will only support your own views.
And that's what he has been doing since the elections.
(Foreign language spoken)
Alassane Ouattara, Gbagbo's political rival, is the U.N.-certified winner of November's disputed election.
Unlike Gbagbo, he faces neither sanctions nor a travel ban.
But Ouattara has no freedom of movement or access to the national airwaves.
Guarded by U.N.
peacekeepers, he remains in a hotel here in Abidjan, blockaded by loyalist Gbagbo troops.
Yes, I'm at the Golf Hotel.
I've been in the hotel now since November 28th.

That was Ouattara speaking in mid-January, from his refuge, addressing a videoconference in Washington, at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, reaching a limited audience, mostly online.
(Soundbite of television program)
Unidentified Man #3: (Foreign language spoken)
One outlet that airs the views of both the Ouattara and Gbagbo governments is the widely listened to United Nations radio station ONUCI FM, run by the U.N.
peacekeeping mission.
Last Wednesday, Gbagbo's authorities ordered the station off the air.
But it's still broadcasting, says the radio's director Sylvain Semilinko, despite death threats to staff members.
We are not biased towards Mr. Gbagbo or Mr. Ouattara.
We just have to do our best in a professional manner.
(Soundbite of song, ""This is Our Land"")
(Singing in foreign language)
This is Our Land"" and other patriotic songs bombard the pro-Gbagbo airwaves.
Such themes are the mantra of Charles Ble Goude, who regularly mobilizes Gbagbo's hostile and youthful Young Patriot supporters with his fiery rhetoric.
(Foreign language spoken)
His critics call Ble Goude the Minister of the Mob.
Gbagbo's youth minister is under international sanctions.
Again, political analyst Gilles Yabi.
Young Patriots can be mobilized very quickly to defend the interest of Laurent Gbagbo on the street.
This system is very efficient in creating chaos or at least in threatening chaos.
